review: WTF?? Do not show your support for this greed ,unbelievable !!!
review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Bethesda" versuchten bezahlte Mods für Skyrim im Steam-Workshop einzuführen, d.h. kostenpflichtige Zusatzinhalte, die direkt über Steam für das Spiel heruntergeladen werden konnten. Allerdings sollten dabei nur 25 % der Einnahmen an die Entwickler der Mods gehen und der Rest an Bethesda und Valve (der Firma hinter Steam). Da das von vielen Spielern als Versuch der Entwickler gesehen wurde, von der Arbeit der Modder selbst zu profitieren, und viele der Meinung waren, Mods sollten grundsätzlich kostenlos sein, hinterließen einige negative Reviews für Skyrim.

review:
You are destroying the what mods are for, mods should be free. Mods are made by people who want to help give people a better experience, by making people charge for mods you are splitting the modding community in 2 halfs, please don't ruin what it means to be a modder, and because of this I am bringing my vote to a no, I no longer recomend this game to ANYONE

Edit: My review is staying negitive forever, I do not care what they say "they wanted to support the modder" it is clear they just wanted to earn a profit, no matter what they said they've not even talked about a donate button, a donate button would've been perfect but no you wanted money and do not care about this community, I loved your games and I still do, but I have now just lost faith in value and bethesada, I really thought you guys cared about the modders and the gamers who buy your games, but you just keep wanting our money, so I just no longer like your company and I don't even think I'll ever buy another one of your games

review:
Skyrim was pretty great game, not my favorite of the Elder Scrolls series (that would be Morrowind), but still fun.  It wasn't able to hold my attention for too long, however. Something about the game, the menus, the items, the combat, the world, something didn't feel right. Something was missing. After playing 50+ hours of the xbox 360 version and constantly seeing all the cool things players could do on the pc I finally decided to upgrade my poor old desktop pc to a monster gaming rig.

That's right, Skyrim, or rather what pc players could do to it, made me join the pc master race. And it was almost entirely because of the one thing that the pc has always had that consoles lack: Mods.

Well, now that is changing. Valve and Bethesda have conspired to take what was once a passion project of dedicated gamers and monetize it. Look how well that's working out for them.

Skyrim is a fine game, but what Valve has done here has actually made it a worse idea to play on pc than to play on consoles. Don't stand for it. Don't indulge them. Vote with your wallets and refuse to pay for what was once free and refuse to encourage greedy, predatory practices like monetized mods.
review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Bethesda" versuchten bezahlte Mods für Skyrim im Steam-Workshop einzuführen, d.h. kostenpflichtige Zusatzinhalte, die direkt über Steam für das Spiel heruntergeladen werden konnten. review: This game in it's un-modded form is broken, and average at best. Mods fixing bugs, increasing graphical quality, adding needed gameplay elements, make this game great.  All of these things benefit the publisher and platform (Steam) already.  They do not deserve a portion of the profits for things made by others work that increase the value of their game. They are essentially forcing modders to pay them to make their product better.  If they want to help modders make a profit, allow donations, but to take a portion of that is disgusting and greedy, especially when they already benefit from the free labor and increased game value of the mods already.

review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Bethesda" versuchten bezahlte Mods für Skyrim im Steam-Workshop einzuführen, d.h. kostenpflichtige Zusatzinhalte, die direkt über Steam für das Spiel heruntergeladen werden konnten. Allerdings sollten dabei nur 25 % der Einnahmen an die Entwickler der Mods gehen und der Rest an Bethesda und Valve (der Firma hinter Steam). Da das von vielen Spielern als Versuch der Entwickler gesehen wurde, von der Arbeit der Modder selbst zu profitieren, und viele der Meinung waren, Mods sollten grundsätzlich kostenlos sein, hinterließen einige negative Reviews für Skyrim.

review:
I'll start out by saying that I've enjoyed Skyrim. With the vibrant modding community, a game that on its own is an interesting, but very buggy and somewhat tedious affair has become an extremely enjoyable experience. All due to the efforts over the years by many people. 

However, with Valve now allowing others to sell mods, and even mods that have been free and downright /necessary/ for an enjoyable experience, such as SkyUI, I can no longer recommend this game to others. Even at the current discount price, buying this game now would support this atrocious move by Valve. Do not support the sale of mods by buying this game, and do not buy paid mods.

review:
Skyrim, when it works, is very time consuming and entertaining. When it doesnt, well, lets just say that it's the opposite. This isnt a unique attribute of Skyrim, most games that are not working (be it due to bugs or crashes or anything) arent enjoyable experiences. 

Skyrim gets its negative rating from me due to the frequency with which the game will crash, the AI bug out, or any number of other game-breaking problems occur. This can get so frequent that it is often not worth even trying to get the game to work.

review:
With the monitization of mods, I can not recommend this game.  In Bethseda's defense, taking 1.5 times more than a service that hosts your software to download makes sense.  However, since Valve takes 30%, it leaves creators with only 25% from each sale, and they demand that modders must make $100 USD before receiving any money at all.  That means for a modder to see any money, they have to sell $400 worth of mods before even seeing a dime.

The current paid mod workplace is filled with cash for gold, overpowered weapons and armor, stolen content, and various mods designed to break your game to force you to reinstall.

Overnight, Valve has destroyed a community that was driven not by "money as information" but goodwill and user feedback.  Bravo.

review:
Steam and Bethesda are desperately trying to squeeze as much money from their customers as they possibly can, to the detriment of the gaming community as a whole. Paid mods ruins this game. Terrible mechanisms come into play through their introduction, for instance mod theft, people pulling free mods because of that, the encouragement of developers to release unfinished content (because they can make money on modders fixing their games). It could be viewed as an attempt by steam to monopolize the modding scene by encouraging modders to abandon free alternatives like Nexus to make a few bucks (a measly 25% of the profit).

Steam needs competitors! Perhaps GOG Galaxy could be one.

review:
What really made this game great was mods.  After nearly 4 years and an expansive mod community, Skyrim was really great in the terms of value you saw added to this game, and it's really what kept this game relevant this long.  While I understand and agree that some modders may want to cash in on their work, the current implementation of this is poorly done.

The fact that it's been so poorly curated (we're already seeing junk mods for $99.99 being added) is fracturing the community.  Modders are seeing their work ripped off and sold without their knowledge, and some mods require other mods to work.  When mods like SkyUI go up behind paywalls (it already is becoming premium only) it's breaking several other mods which rely on SkyUI as a backbone.  It's turning modders against modders and modders against gamers, and to top that all off, the modders who are putting out paid mods are making Valve and Bethesda rich for their own hard work.  

The current mess that the state of this game is in makes it not worth my recommendation.  If the current paid mods fiasco was implemented in a way that makes any sense, I might reverse my rating.

review:
Bethesda and Valve ruin a good community for more profit, All around awful idea.

I enjoyed playing Skyrim and the Steam workshop offered accessible mods that made the game pretty much endlessly fun. I would never say modders don't deserve some profit for good work, but this is not the right way to do it and also they aren't even the ones who will profit from this, just Valve because you can receive refunds for mods. Theres no good way to regulate this either, we'll see plenty of pirating of any these mods.

I lost my computer last year in a flood, I've been saving for months to buy a new one mostly for Steam games. After this however, I think I'll just save the money and find a new hobby. Companies choose to screw with good things to make marginal profits, Valve or Bethesda will NOT get another penny out of me.

review:
A few years back a good game was launched named Skyrim. The game felt kind of empty with many limits, shortcomings and a short storyline but was still good. A few modders started to share their first creations and as the community grew, more and more mods and sub-communities saw the day. The work to improve and expand the game was well on its way. The community created tools and resources that other modders used. Ideas was discussed and fantastic mods was created. Today more than 40000 mods is hosted on nexus and the workshop have more than 25000 mods. Countless numbers of videos, reviews, feedbacks and play testing have been produced. The game have expanded and improved in all aspects and the selection of mods,improvements and information is tremendous.

The community surrounding Skyrim have become very large and the popularity of the game followed that growth. And much of this was built on the idea that everyone was free to use the mods and tools that was created by the community. All that changed when Bethesda made it possible to charge money for mods. This change in policy is moving Bethesda in a direction that is undermining the foundation for the popularity and interested around their games. This change in policy will split up the community, create conflicts and reduce number of new mods created. Many will feel betrayed and treated unfairly and those that made the resource and tools that made some of the best mods possible will never be paid.

I'm not against that modders get paid for their work, I'm against the way it was introduced, that they introduced it in a well established community and the way it work on steam. By using Skyrim as the first game that have this "paying for mod" system it just feels like they are trying to **** out all the cash they can from this community that was built around free sharing and that already have thousand of mods available for sale. And in return they only give 25% to the modders, its easy to see that this was not act of being kind to the community.
review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Bethesda" versuchten bezahlte Mods für Skyrim im Steam-Workshop einzuführen, d.h. kostenpflichtige Zusatzinhalte, die direkt über Steam für das Spiel heruntergeladen werden konnten. Allerdings sollten dabei nur 25 % der Einnahmen an die Entwickler der Mods gehen und der Rest an Bethesda und Valve (der Firma hinter Steam). review:
I have almost 200 hours in this game. You know why? Because mods that's why. The freedom to mix and match any mods on a whim. Being able to look up an issue you have, like maybe you find it annoying that you can't dual cast two different spells, and searching for a mod that does just that, downloading, and installing it in a matter of minutes and having a greater gaming experience as a rusult is the reason I've spent an entire week of my life in this game.

But no more. Now all of those mods are stuck behind a paywall. Now to play this game as I used to enjoy I would have to pay at least 100 bucks to get everything I had installed. Now it's just Vanilla Skyrim. A game I played for 10 hours and dropped it on Xbox. Now as far as Valve is conserned, there is one less advantage to PC gaming and that is truly sad. We pride ourselves in the fact that we play games however we want, but now instead of asking ourselves "how would I like to play this game" we'll have to ask "How much am I willing to pay to play this game the way I want?" And that does nothing to help Valve or PC gaming in general.

I am forced to review this game as it were Vanilla now. Because I cannot in good conscience say "this game is great as long as you're willing to put 50 bucks into it!" Which it is. But without mods this game is as wide as the ocean, but deep as a puddle. You'll do the main quest and feel like you had no effect on the world around. People will treat you as a random traveler no matter how many dragon souls you absorb.

If Valve ever get their heads on straight and withdraws this program I would gladly revise this review to reflect what an amazing experience this 5 dollar game could bring, but I sadly can't do that now.

review:
This was my first foray into the world of Elder Scrolls.  I found it to be full of fetch quests and forced sightseeing unless I wanted to break immersion by making extensive use of the fast travel system once you eventually visit a location.  One of the draws to this game for me was the mods, but it seems that if I want to enjoy some of the more appealing ones the game will cost me more than the price tag actually indicates.

What happened to the good old days when you bought a polished, finished product that could stand on its own as a satisfying experience?

review:
Skyrim is a fantastic game, well worth Steam's full price.

That being said, however, I would not advise anyone to buy this game. Recently, Valve decided to implement a broken system in which users can charge for their mods on the workshop. This has led to extensive copyright infringement, the stifling of creativity, loss of quality control, and greed. Overall, it has divided the once thriving and friendly modding community in two, and I would advise anyone to not give Valve your money for this game until they undo the broken system they've put in and replace it with a donation button.

Valve has done this, they claim, so "players can give back to modders for their work", however the fact that only 25% of the profits goes to modders reveals the true nature of Valve's intent; a money ploy for themselves and Bethesda, in which they recieve 75% of the profits for something they had no involvement in. Furthermore, many steam users posting their thoughts on the forums have been suspended for a week or more from steam, their comments taken down.

Skyrim is a great game, made even greater by the mods that the generous community has put out for years. It's really too bad it had to come to this...

This review will be taken down once Valve announces that paid modding will be no more.

review:
It's a great game that owes part of its success to free mods. As long as paid mods are a thing I can not recommend this game, Skyrim is not Skyrim without mods.

Edit: Valve has removed the paid mods from Skyrim, but its clear they are still planning to milk mods for money. They have apologized not for the paid mods but for trying it out on Skyrim, so the paid mods will be back in another game. If they are implemented right and the community is informed before hand, not like what they did for Skyrim, they could work. That being said even though the paid mods are gone for now it has left me with a sour taste in my mouth and I find I can't recommend Skyrim just yet even though its one of my favorite games on steam.

review:
Money grubbing on a 4 year old game? No thank you. As many hours as I have enjoyed Skyrim I can no longer play this game and enjoy myself seeing how far the platform and developer are willing to go to mees with the one thing that KEPT this game (and so many other buggy games) alive and still highly played well after their release cycle. With the new paid mods, so many efforts of the community which was fine with NO help from the dev or platform have been shat down the drain. 

Skyrim is filled with bugs and some areas even unplayable without the use of mods. When a dev just leaves bug fixes to the community then trys to monetize that same community's hard work for their own game (75% of the cut really?) is it just disgusting.

I will be moving all of my business to other websites and direct to the developers.  Bethesda and Valve you had a good run but I really detest unherhandded business practices and blatant betrayal of the community. I will vote with my wallet until paid mods are fully removed. P.S. that "AMA" was so pandering and full of coporate double speak it wasn't even funny.

review:
The base game of Skyrim is buggy and CTD often, the main story is boring and without mods this game is broken.

If it wasn't for modding this game would have died years ago, and now thanks to paid mods there will be a
pay wall for things like GUI fixes that the modding community made.

Bethesda takes a 45% cut from all paid mod sales Valve take 30% and the modder gets 25% there is no way to get a refund of real money if you buy a mod and it doesn't work you have a 24 hour period in which you can be refunded store credit not real money.

There is also no way to be sure what a mod is like because Steam have locked the forums for these paid mods unless you buy them so they expect you to buy blind.

There is also no way to insure consumer are protected from mods being dropped or patching causing games to break and people buying mods may be left out of pocket with a broken game/save due to bad modding.

review:
Having already invested many hours on other platforms, I decided to purchase the game on steam to support the devs and perhaps revisit the game in the future with the help of the vast modding community (Hence the low amount of recorded hours). Unfortunately Valve/Bethesda has come up with a stupid paywall for mods which makes the game hard to recommend to anyone. Mods is what makes this game great, and yeah, they're still there, in the form of paid DLC. What has started here won't end here. It only sets precedent as to what comes next. The next Elder Scolls? Other Bethesda titles? Influencing other publishers/developers to follow?

Don't support this game and its mission to monetize mods.

review: Two words : Paid Mods . Enough said. Now you might ask Why such a big fuss about mods ? Well , you see , mods are a quintesential part to gaming in general both keeping games alive for many many years and providing a third party support source when the developers fail. This modding community has existed for ages and had no problem doing this for free (and they still don't have any problem with it). But alas , corporations like Bethesda/Zenimax and Valve are greedy and want to destroy a pillar of the gaming culture yet again . First were the dlcs now , unless we do something , there will be paid mods.

review:
Skyrim is a pretty decent game. Skyrim with mods is an totally awesome game. Skyrim with paid mods, however, is a s***pile. There is no way to know if a new paid mod will conflict with another mod - and there will be conflicts. Hundreds of them. Trust me on this.   There's no way to know if it'll even work - one of the mods that's being showcased as I write this adds an item, but there's no way of getting the item ingame without the console. You have no way of knowing if the mod has been ripped off of another mod, thus cheating the original creator of what's his/hers. There's already 'free' versions of mods with ads in them! Ads! in a mod!

Free mods made by enthusiastic modders are the best thing ever.
Paid mods made by moneygrabbers are the equivalent of mobile apps.

review:
Like most Bethesda games, Skyrim is only mediocre when played without mods. With mods, the cool factor rises a million times over. Mods let you change almost every element of the game, adding immeasurable fun, and replay value. With that said, this is going to be a negative review because Bethesda, and Valve, have enabled a system where modders can now sell their mods on Steam.

This act has already led to some modders pulling their mods from free sites like Nexus. Why is it a bad thing for modders to be paid for their work? Because that's not what modding is all about. I also mod, but I would never charge someone for something that is essentially done for fun, and with the notion of sharing with others. Modding has always been something done by the fans ****, for other fans of the game.

For companies like Steam, and Bethesda, to try to monetize that, is nothing more than greed. And get this, the modders only recieve 25% of what they charge for their mods. Guess who gets the other 75%. This move sets a really bad precedent for things to come. You may not play Skyrim, but what if Valve started doing this to all their games? Modders for all games could potentially start charging people, and then the whole modding community would just turn into a huge market that nets big money for greedy corporations.

So, though I had fun with it in the past, I do not recommend Skyrim to anyone. It's your call to get it, but when the only thing that makes the game any good, is about to become paid DLC, that's when the game turns foul in my mind.
Posted April 23.

review: Coming from Morrowind, I'm just sad that people have to hide their mods in fear of thieves stealing their hard work (without monetary compensation) and selling them here. That's just the start of the downhill, because if you do get your mod stole, Valve and Bethesda doesn't care, as they said "let the people fix their problems". And then if you remove all the bad people stealing mods, modders get 25% cut (75% to bethesda+valve) and that's in STEAM CURRENCY!, and you can't even withdraw if you earned too little, as they have a minimum withdrawl. Tell me how paying so low to modders help the community, how filling it with half assed cosmetic items will better the quality, or how this gives an incentive to huge modders like Skywind. Shame on you, Bethesda and Valve, two more fallen to the greed.

review:
This game with mods is great. Introducing a paywall and trying to sell previously free content? Giving the content creators a fraction of the money? Breaking the modding community? Shame on you Valve/Bethesda. The whole benefit of buying this game (and similar games on PC) is for the modding opportunities. If you take that away (or monetize it) you breed bad feeling and remove the sole purpose of getting the game on this platform on the first place. Introducing this system retroactively is an even worse idea.
People may have hundreds of mods. What happens if large numbers of them rely on a mod that has now become paid and the person doesn't want to/ can't afford to pay whatever they are charging? Congratulations, you just broke their game.

review:
[EDIT:Awesome, paid mods are gone! Still won't change my review. I still feel like I've been backstabbed in some way by Valve/Bethesda, that beeing they messed up a great community overnight and the days that followed and the ridiculous 75% share. I paid good money for this game and they wanted to get more from us. Let this serve as a reminder to them both. Also, a Dontation button shouldn't be that hard to implement Valve.] 

This negative review if because of the paid mods. Everything use to be free, and now we're seeing alot of mods that used to be free go paid. I'm pointing at you iNeed - Food Water and Sleep *cough* (Older version free on Skryim Nexus. 1.6 version paid on Workshop with a few more extra ways to get water.) This game by itself sits on a 10/10, with probably the best replayability ever. The gameplay is amazing, the graphics are beautiful lots of quests especially with the extra DLC's. If you're here for that reason, defo buy the game.

Though if you want this game on PC for the mods, make sure to head to Skyrim Nexus (google it) where everything is free and there is an optional Donate button. Because Valve is trying to cash in on this Workshop. I'm 100% behind people getting paid for their work, but not when a Monopolist like Valve gets 75% of it (Shared with Bethesda.) and the people that actually create the content, with a ''free and released by Bethesda'' creation kit / their own tools, only get 25% of the that price and that's AFTER they reach $100 or more in sales. What I don't support however, is some mods that were always free suddenly get updates because they're able to get money for them, and not updating it on Skyrim Nexus. It makes me sick.

review:
Taking money from the community with no guarantee with stability and keeping 75% away from the creators? #onlyBethesda

MAYBE 4 hours of main story gameplay. I beat this game overnight on the day of release... I was so confused. Was that it, was there REALLY nothing more to the game than that? Yes. Sure, there are numerous sidequests I did not complete but most of them are nothing more than reskinned fetch quests... For the size of the world the horses are painfulyl slow and thus i found myself quicktraveling nearly EVERYWHERE. Without mods I MIGHT have 7 hours TOTAL logged in the game.

review:

To fix this, you'll need mods.  Oh yeah, for 4 years now, they've been free, until Valve and Bethesda decided to get greedy.  Yeah, that changed it all.  So those essential mods you'd want to "fix" your game and make it awesome.  Guess what, you're paying for unsupported DLC now.  So, not able to recommend this game now.

review:
Skyrim is a fun game, but to get the best experience, you need to install a bunch of mods. These mods are made by hobbyists, who want to do something good for the community, in an environment of mutual co-operation, honest criticism, and an urge to try new things. It's pretty much the last safe haven from the cynical strategies of manufactured blockbusters and DLC.

Now this fine tradition is under attack from corporate fat cats who want to earn a slice of the pie for doing nothing. It amounts to the routine exploitation of hobbyists. This isn't just a bad business move, though; it hurts the game. Already, we have seen free versions of mods incorporate nags to upgrade to the paid verison. We've seen modders take their work off the Nexus because frauds are stealing their work and uploading it for a fee on the Workshop. We've also seen free mods taken down and uploaded exclusive to the Workshop, hidden behind a paywall. I'm not sure how anyone could sustain the argument that this will result in a better product, or that it doesn't affect everyone adversely.

Perhaps most disturbingly, the move incentivises publishers to coerce develoepers into releasing a faulty or incomplete game, because they stand to benefit from the content and fixes that the community will surely provide. They might as well lay off some of their staff as well, because they have a plentiful source of cheap labour in hobbyists.

Don't listen to the lies of those who advocate paid mods. Tell a friend about the disturbing precedent that was set last week by Valve and Bethesda. Free the mods!
review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Bethesda" versuchten bezahlte Mods für Skyrim im Steam-Workshop einzuführen, d.h. kostenpflichtige Zusatzinhalte, die direkt über Steam für das Spiel heruntergeladen werden konnten. review: Skyrim is a mediocre fantasy hack-and-slash with boring Fedex quests, unmemorable NPCs, shallow combat mechanics, ok graphics, terrible UI, and the list goes on. Despite its flaws, it sold millions and continues to be popular thanks to the wonderful modding community. But money grubbing Bethesda and Valve aren't satisfied until they milk their fanbase dry. They monetize mods under the guise of supporting modders, while taking 75% of the profits for doing absolutely nothing. This system is shameful, manipulative and benefits only the corporations, not the gamers or modders. Say no to paid mods!

review:
This game has it's problems, and it's strong points.

Bethesda tends to release expansive, games, brimming with potential, but their eyes also tend to be too big for their stomach so to speak. They end up releasing games brimming with bugs (Also in many of their games they seem incapable of actually making a normal humanoid head. Skyrim was the best so far at this). They've relied heavily on the mod community to fix these things after the beginnings of it in Daggerfall (where modding wasn't supported), with Morrowind, it was full on support for mods, and someone at Bethsoft should have rightfully gotten a huge pay raise. It helped make tons of loyal fans for the entire series, and if you think it didn't affect the success of the games? You are likely delusional.

Here are my problems with it.

Dumbed down. The removal of several systems that were present in previous iterations of the series were not an improvement. Skyrim often feels like it lacks customization.

Magic kind of ****. It's been kind of going downhill for the entire series though, but there are several seemingly confusing oversights. Such as the lack of mark and recall spells.

Where are my vambraces? Sentence says it all.

The biggest downside now though: Paid mods. Yes the thing that skyrim relied on heavily since it's launch, and the thing Bethesda has been relying on for, idk a decade or so, is now open to purchase. Just like DLC, aren't you excited consumer? Oh and the creator of the content gets 25%, 45% going to bethsoft, and 30% going to Valve. So the person doing the work, gets a quarter on every dollar. Clearly a framework based on the outright exploitation of the work of others for financial gain. The legal issues alone are staggering, unlicensed student versions of 3dsmax, appropriation of the assets of others under a non-commercial license suddenly appearing in commercial mods, outright theft of mods, the fracturing of the modding community. It's a bad thing. They did this game in, but hopefully we can all stop it here. Paid mods? No more.
review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Bethesda" versuchten bezahlte Mods für Skyrim im Steam-Workshop einzuführen, d.h. kostenpflichtige Zusatzinhalte, die direkt über Steam für das Spiel heruntergeladen werden konnten. Allerdings sollten dabei nur 25 % der Einnahmen an die Entwickler der Mods gehen und der Rest an Bethesda und Valve (der Firma hinter Steam). Da das von vielen Spielern als Versuch der Entwickler gesehen wurde, von der Arbeit der Modder selbst zu profitieren, und viele der Meinung waren, Mods sollten grundsätzlich kostenlos sein, hinterließen einige negative Reviews für Skyrim.

review:
First I want to say; I own skyrim for the xbox with over 180 hours played and think it's a fantastic game, even as a standalone. 

I've always wanted to have the pc version of Skyrim to play some of the mods I've seen for it. Well thanks to Valve and Bethesda I can't enjoy the modded skyrim experience without being sure to give them even more money!  

I think it's absolutely crazy that Bethesda has made over a BILLION dollars on skyrim yet they want to take 75% of every 'paid mod' offered in the Steam workshop. Same goes for you, Valve. I'm sure you've made a LOT of money off Skyrim and it's disgusting how greedy the both of you are being. You both are multi billion dollar companies but let's take some more of our communities money by doing 0 work and making 75% of the profits! 

You remind me of Congress. Soon as the question of pay raises for themselves is brought to the table, it's the fastest thing Congress passes next to Mexican food.

I will buy this game (I played the trial) as soon as modding returns to what it was instead of another funnel directly into Valve/Bethesda's greedy overflowing pockets.

Allerdings sollten dabei nur 25 % der Einnahmen an die Entwickler der Mods gehen und der Rest an Bethesda und Valve (der Firma hinter Steam). Da das von vielen Spielern als Versuch der Entwickler gesehen wurde, von der Arbeit der Modder selbst zu profitieren, und viele der Meinung waren, Mods sollten grundsätzlich kostenlos sein, hinterließen einige negative Reviews für Skyrim.

review: Let's be honest, vanilla Skyrim is a 7/10 game.  Good but, forgettable.  Mods is what really made Skyrim shine as a 10/10 game.  Mods can significantly change the gameplay of a playthrough for the better.  With the possibility that mods turning into the new payable DLC is going to change the gaming industry for the worst.  Bethesda introduced DLC in Oblivion with horse armor and that gained momentum for better or worse.  Now I take a stand and don't want Bethesda to introduce P2P mods as the new norm for the gaming industry.  What'll be next?  Having to pay irl money for each quest or each new piece of armor in the next Elder Scroll game?  In the next Fallout Game?  In any new game post 2015?

review:
I've played TES since Daggerfall and have always been impressed by the culture of modding surrounding the series. That culture has been assaulted in the past few days by Valve and Bethesda, solely to make profit, which is both disheartening and insulting. The fact that they would corrupt such a beautiful artistic culture which has existed for longer than either company by attempting to own it is disgusting. The two faced nature of this, first saying that they wish to support modders, and then disrupting attempts to collect donations and taking 75% of all sales made by modders, as well as the general shady dealings of Valve simply compounds the issue.

This is not their hobby, they are not modders, they wish to own modding, which oughtn't be owned. This cannot be allowed.

Allerdings sollten dabei nur 25 % der Einnahmen an die Entwickler der Mods gehen und der Rest an Bethesda und Valve (der Firma hinter Steam). Da das von vielen Spielern als Versuch der Entwickler gesehen wurde, von der Arbeit der Modder selbst zu profitieren, und viele der Meinung waren, Mods sollten grundsätzlich kostenlos sein, hinterließen einige negative Reviews für Skyrim.

review:
Assassin's Creed Unity remains by far one of the most astoundingly beautiful and visually appealing games I've ever played, even now, 5 years down the line. With minimal bugs (at least in the version I have), it truly brings out the streets of Paris and the atmosphere of the Revolution in an amazing way. 

With regards to the story, I believe it could have been done much better. I was really into it in the beginning few sequences, but it got to be a bit of a drag later on. The storyline with Bellec, especially, I think was a missed opportunity, not to mention that it could have made the Assassin-Templar struggle more immersed and intertwined with the Revolution itself. I was especially disappointed that the story didn't really involve Napoleon too much, and that Arno didn't really seem to have any growth, except into a cocky prick with a chip on his shoulder.

Regarding the gameplay itself, there are aspects I enjoyed and those I hated. I'm personally a fan of the return to the single hidden blade, and I loved how it could only really be used for executions, much like in the original Assassin's Creed. I loved the fact that they scaled up the combat difficulty, which meant that you had no choice but to be extremely judicious and tactical in how you approached conflict. I'm not a fan of the stealth mechanics, however, since there are some things from the older games that you cannot do in this one, like carrying corpses around, whistling from hiding spots, and such, which really made for frustrating gameplay. The fact that your enemies couldn't parkour like you could seemed to be very fitting, since I can't really imagine gendarme and soldiers clambering across the Paris rooftops, all the while carrying their muskets, axes and such. The parkour was an absolute joy, though I think they could have refined it a lot more. This was the most buggy aspect of my game, and it felt quite clunky, taking away from the entire immersiveness. The sheer number of chests in the game is really unnecessary, and it was a chore to hunt them all down. 

All this being said, I did enjoy the game, and I'd recommend it as a buy. Besides, it's dirt cheap on steam, anyway, so you'll get a value for your money whatever your personal impressions of the game

review:
I honestly did enjoy the story but it was beyond irritating with all the bugs and mess I had to go through to make it playable. It was also a nightmare to record/stream. It just had horrible frame rate and it was just this game. Once I got it going though it was fun and enjoyable. The voice acting was amazing, visuals were nice, co op missions were fun with friends (not so much with randos.)

The mechanics were one of the best ones I have used since starting this series and I can't wait to see how the other ones after this one live up to it.

review: The  last Assassin's Creed game I played was 2 on my Xbox 360, so I haven't really kept up on all the new gameplay changes and whatnot. But I loved this game. At the time of the review, I am on the last mission and then gotta do the DLC. The movement in this game is the most fluid movement I have seen in an Assassin's Creed game. (While I didn't play any of the others really, I did see gameplay for most of them.) I am also a huge sound snob, and the sound design for this game is fantastic. Everything from the sword clashes to the foot steps while running through the streets of Paris sounded amazing. And speaking of Paris, the city itself is very beautiful. It is also so lively. I'm not sure if this is a new mechanic or was added in in an earlier game, but also having the Crowd Events to deal with while you are running around the city is very fun and immersive in my opinion. I find it very fun to be running down a street, crowd event triggers, quick run assassination, then continue running. I usually loot the bad guys, but sometimes I just skip that. Overall the game is very very fun, and I highly recommend it. As for bugs, the worst one I ran into was simply some patrolling or running thieves/enemies getting caught on crowds when trying to walk/run through them. I was able to walk through them just fine myself. But with the amount of people walking around the streets, you are bound to run into people getting stuck on each other from time to time. Great game, and got me back into Assassin's Creed again.

review:
tl;dr: Definetely recommend.

I bought this game on sale alongside all the other games of the franchise and to be honest I wasn't expecting much of it since it gets destroyed by critics since release. Turns out Unity became my favorite AC game. 

The parkour here is the best in the series, smooth and stylish, although some may find it a bit unrealistic; Arno may not be the best main character from the series, but he's definetely stylish, charming and goes through a lot of stuff, which made me get personally attached to him.

This game, in my opinion, is the one I feel the most true Assassin vibes from, it's so much fun to stealth in this game. I don't know about release, but RIGHT NOW the game is pretty solid and still has bugs, but minimal ones, it doesn't ruin anything, people should stop crying so much. Plus, the Co-op and Heist features are a plus here, really fun to play and unique.

Story is kind of bland, wouldn't say it's great, but it's not bad either, it's alright since it's not the strong point of this game. Plus, Dead Kings DLC is pretty fun, one of my favorites. Definetely recommend this, even if you have to buy it.

review:
It's not a bad game for me, even I got lots of glitches like falling down from the map, got stuck in the wall while climbing, etc.

Story & gameplay is pretty good. Combat system is better than Syndicate. 
Parkour mechanic feels kinda smooth, but sometime it's just out of the place. 
Lots of customizations.
Lots of citizens that perfect opportunity for blending in, but I feel like it's too much (There's a lot of NPCs in this game). 
And I think the DLCs are not worth it.
Can't start a new game.

This could be my favorite Assassin's Creed game, if only it's not too glitchy.
My score: 6.9/10

Also, the story is implemented really well in this time period.

review: Ubisoft is pledging money to help rebuild Notre Dame and letting researchers use their recreation, I've always enjoyed this game I first got it on PS4 about 6 months after it launched after all the patches fixed it up. I've also always enjoyed the Assassin's Creed series as a history lover due to the fact that they bring so much eras to life The American Revolution, The Italian Renaissance, Victorian London, and of course Paris during the French Revolution, this game will always have a soft spot in my heart I love French Revolution and Napoleonic history and am glad that despite it's rocky launch it is getting some positive attention

review: This game actually gets it meaning from its title itself. Its a story of Unity of Love. How a assassin loves a templar and they fight together to take down the corruption in France. The game also has coop modes which is new to the series and only available from this game and onwards. Relive the French Revolution and cleanse France from The corruption of the templars and get ready for a unwanted betrayal from your own kin. Cheers!

review:
The only criticism you could give to Unity is the bugs that has been mostly fixed. (and you know the abundance of collectibles) 
Everything else is just so good. For example:

- You can go inside a lot of houses (idk why but I love that shit)
- Solving murder cases
- Stunning visuals
- Selection of melee weapon types
- One of the best parkour controls and movement imo
- Riddle solving (kinda hard but it's there)

review: Saying I was an assassin inside the Notre Dame in this video game and tactically calculating how to take said man's life in a building that has been a part of my life for most of it. Most note worthy appearance would have to be the Hump back of Notre Dame, many of us have watched this but it show cases the depth of the structure. I love hearing that company's that I have supported by purchasing MANY of their games sometimes twice with my wife make donations to make the world great or preserve some of the things that make us all want to make a good difference in the world. This game aims to be accurate and they are even using this games digital reconstruction of the building to start the re-build. Just, wow... :)

review:
What a heartbreaking game... Just one more year in the oven and it would've been the best AC since 2. All the greatness is there; You'll have many moments during the story cinematics that make you say "How is this so quality while on the other hand there are flying Parisians?"

Also: Best parkour in the series. Don't understand why Ubi has pretty much taken it out from the new games.

review: This is an alright game to the Assassins Creed series. However, I don't find the story as intense and great as the previous games like Assassins Creed II. However I do like the idea of having a co-op mode, only downside is that the required hardware for this game is ridiculous, I was able to run Assassins Creed Syndicate perfectly fine on a GTX 670, i5, 16gb DDR2 Ram build, However had troubles running this game. Overall this game is alright, not the best. The declining parkour mechanics where smooth and nice but this game needs to be optimised in order for it to be somewhat decent to run on lower end PC's.

review:
I am writing this review because it was the first game i pre-order on Steam. I was watching the trailer and gameplay of the Assassin's Creed Unity and I thought this was a great game with the multiplayer Co-op with your friends on the missions at the same time. Then there were some problems about the glitches and bugs (haha, i remember seeing those inside out face of one character and randomly NPC pop-ups and the player falling down the white abyss).

Maybe i didn't had a great time with the game because i was using my laptop at first run but i did enjoy the game.
But i heard the game was more stable after a few years later and playable.

review: Awesome setting, surprisingly few bugs, great story and protagonist, but the controls are ABYSMAL!  I really want to like this, and mostly I do, but this game feels like its fighting me. The difficulty sometimes seems cheap, like the controls or a stupidly long finisher animation costing you your life or allowing the enemies to reach the alarms. Getting all the stupid badges is a real grind. In fact, "grind" is a good word to describe the negatives here. 100% this and you'll have spent a massive amount of time doing it. Even so, its a real achievement and obviously a lot of work went into this game. Incredible detail, awesome customization options, a massive world and the graphics are absolutely gorgeous. With a bit more polish and streamlining it could have been one of the best in the series. 7.5 out of 10, awesome game that gets in it's own way a bit too often...but it grows on you.

review: I've had this game for a while and figured I'd just give it a quick review. It's a fun game, not amazing but the graphics are pretty damn good and IMO it has the best assassination animations of any AC game all the way up to Odyssey. This game, again IMO, has probably the best stealth in the series so far. You get quite a large arsenal of tools to use for stealth like the smoke bombs, phantom blades, berserker blades, poison bombs, stun grenades, etc. The parkour is also SUPER satisfying once you get the hang of it. The character customization is alright, better than every game before AC4 but Origins/Odyssey do it better. Overall, it's a fun game. The stealth is great and combined with the parkour you'll feel like a real assassin. I give this game an 8/10 (not 10/10 because the story's a fucking bore fest).

review: I really liked this one.  I've played all of the AC series in order, but I've played them several years after launch.  So I've just play Unity in January of 2019 and all of the bugs from launch were fixed.  The game ran smoothly on my older rig except for chapter 9.  Regardless, this was a great game.  I wasn't excited for it, as revolutionary France isn't particularly interesting to me, but I found Paris to be beautiful and the game play fun.  After having just come off of Black Flag and Freedom Cry, the way you go about sneaking around is a bit different.  There are few bushes or corn fields to hid in, but you have the ability to  crouch and you only have one hidden blade rather than two, which most players would have probably gotten used to if they've been playing since the beginning of the series.  I still think Black Flag is the most fun up to this point, but this is great, has a great story, great setting, and the game play is fun.

It may have been a buggy mess when it was launched, but not anymore after Ubi's bug fixes:
- Smooth Movements, Parkour
- Intuitive, Enjoyable combat

review:
Well, Assassin's Creed Unity is an Assassin's Creed game, with everything it implies in great settings and totally assisted but still frustratingly imprecise gameplay.
So I won't do a review of every Assassin's Creed game here and will just focus on the particularities of Unity.

Nobody seemed to like Unity, but I actually did. :p
The mistake most players did was to buy the game at release (or even worse in pre-release), when AC2 and AC3 already showed us that every big AC release is rushed and buggy. The good news is that this time was so bad that they actually decided to correct it. So if you play Unity today, you'll get to enjoy a relatively bug-free game with a far better optimized engine.

Unity is still a very standard AC game. The changes are minimal. I think the biggest for me was the openness of most situations. Your targets are in a huge building with many entries and options, making for a more Dishonored-feel to the assassintations.
I must admit that I played this game two or three years after my previous AC game mostly because I needed to update my PC. And so I wasn't to fed up with the AC gameplay. I had kinda missed it. I don't know if I would have enjoyed Unity this much if I just finished my previous AC.

There's actually something that changed from previous AC games, it's the depiction of female characters. The main character is still male (and particularly uninteresting here), but I felt that the teams behind made everything possible to showcase as many interesting female characters as possible. You'll note that half the assassins helping you in the street are female and they fight exactly in the same way as males.
It's too bad Unity got that controversy about sexism in video games when every previous title in the series should have gotten it, but it only happened when the developpers actually tried to make things better.
It would have make things better if the playable character was Elise (who is the actual main character of the story), but I guess the communication department of Ubisoft again enforced their views on the actual productive teams.

review: After reading reviews I was concerned about bugs, but I have played the whole game including DLC and it only crashed once. I played all the previous ACs and enjoyed them, but I enjoyed this one the least so far. I general it was because there is nothing new really. For me Black Flag and Rogue were great because of the ship which added an extra dimension. Unity went back to the old formula and it felt stale. The graphics are great but they don't make up for the resulting problems in gameplay. I like stealth games and it is irritating to be forced into combat when I have Arno stand by a wall, press "cover" again and again but he refuses to do so. As a player of the AC games I am used to feeling like a puppet master who realises that the strings are all tangled, but Unity is one of the worst - trying to get Arno to go through a window can be truly difficult. Then there's the kill animation and the camera angles - how did the designers get it so wrong? I can't help feeling that there was insufficient play testing during development. Or maybe the bugs that they did fix were really so bad that they ended up feeling like the game was finished. It is finished as in complete, but it lacks the quality in playability that it deserves. I think it is the weakest of the AC games. As a result I'm likely to wait a long time before I play Syndicate because it really will have to be a good sale price for be to buy it.

review:
The controls take a bit to get used to as there a bit clunky compared to some of the other Assassin games. However once you have this under controll the visuals and details of the overall world along with the story line absolutely make up for this draw back.
I love this game, just walking around the streets of Paris, visiting places I’ve visited in real life. Paris has been brought to life in game with such detail, noble men and the general public going about there dally lives. U can actual watch print makers, wheal rights, Painters, Tanners and all sorts at work performing each action if u have the patience to hang about and watch. There are markets, alleys and galleries, catacombs, churches, peoples homes and much more to explore. 
There r people from actual history to meet and interact with.
So much love and detail was put into this game it’s a must I my books.
And if that hasn’t convinced you, Assassins Creed Unity is now officially the only way for the foreseeable future for you to walk about and explore Notre-Dame cathedral in all its brilliant majesty. Truly an Architectural wonder both in game and out.
I look forward to maybe joining you in game on some multiplayer adventures.

review:
Assassin's Creed Unity is a unique experience. I've never encountered a game with such a strong sense of time and place. You really feel like you're pushing your way through rioters in 18th century France, in a way that books and movies can't replicate.

Other entries in the series may be more "fun," but they tend to feel more sterilized and video-gamey. More than any of the others, Unity felt like it captured the beauty, filth and chaos of history.

It's a shame the game was so buggy at first, because the patched version is really special. This is one of the few games I go back and replay every couple years. I'm glad it's finally getting the recognition it deserves.

review:
It's a decent part of the AC-franchise.
storywise it's just the same once again: templars are bad, go hunt a bunch and find some artifacts...
fighting system is ok, it just sometimes omits the markers for enemies attacking from the side, otherwise no real flaws

BUT: the controls on pc are awfull compared to the older parts (haven't played the newer ones yet), often times the main character runs off an edge where he wasn't supposed to or climbs up an unneccessary ledge, jump away from the hay because you didn't hit it 100% perfect, ...
Also synchronising is annoying here because you HAVE to use shift+E to climb down from the spot and E synchronises... so if you miss the timeframe where it can't synchronise again (relatively short) you have to watch the whole cutscene again and can't skip it. if you try to go down from those small synchronisation points (like a cross on a church) without E you just jump somewhere and die.

Overall if you're a friend of the franchise go buy it, otherwise you won't miss anything if you skip it(at least outside of sales)

review:
9/10 Totally Underrated.

Despite the big oof at launch, this game is pretty much smooth now

The Highlights:
+++ Atmosphere (The French Revolution atmosphere feels so alive with so many NPCs burning flags, shouting for freedom, carrying  a literal human head stick, and also the guillotines, etc)
+++ Parkour (compared to all of AC games, i feel this one has the most smooth and most realistic parkour mechanics/animations)
+++ Customization (basically have 3 classes which is Stealth, Heavy, and Range. Also i think the costumes/outfit makes you feel like you're a legit cool badass Assassin)
+++ History elements (i'm not a historian or anything but i feel like it's accurate) (The murder mystery missions depicts the french revouliton well imo)

The Bad:
- - - Story (Despite the major connection with another AC title [spoiler] AC:Rouge	[/spoiler], this game spoke nothing of it but instead make a love story lol)

The Meh:
> Combat (slow/clunky combat system but realistic, which i liked, compared to counter-kill system in other AC titles)

review: Held off on this for a long time, partly because of reviews and partly because these games are so gigantic I usually can't play more than one without a big break.  Honestly, the negative press seems way overblown.  I'm into it.  Seems like they've ironed out the bugs.  Most of the game's issues have been there in all of the previous games.  The running can be a little janky, the game can overload you with systems and menus and icons, the story is basically just ok.  I think these were all true of the prior games.  But the graphics are insane, the story at least has strong voice acting, and it seems like they fixed the combat so it's actually difficult now.

review:
I really don't understand all the negativity around this game. Hands down, easily the most beautiful and wholesome Assassin's Creed game to date. Does it glitch? Yeah.. A little.. It's not game breaking, though. But what about the positives? 

1. Absolutely beautiful story. Arno is a very lovable character, so is Elise. Both of them will leave a long lasting impression on you. 

2. The graphics are gorgeous and the music is captivating. 

3. The atmosphere is stunning. Paris is huge, crowded, bustling and it feels alive. Something I haven't felt in an AC game for a long time.

4. Gameplay has been completely revamped. Enemies are less predictable in combat, mis-timing blows WILL lead to punishment, and you can no longer single handedly take down an entire army. You WILL die. They WILL swarm you. Oh, and good luck running away from angry guards. They'll shoot you down without hesitation. Stealth had been made more gratifying. Enemies are a lot more alert, and they WILL detect you if you do something stupid. And if you're detected by one, all of god friends will come to his aid. Detection can be deadly. Simply put, the new gameplay makes combat fun and rewarding, it also makes stealth essential, not superfluous.

5. The game is full of activity and it took me well over 100 hours to complete up to a reasonable percentage. You never get bored. Money well spent. Even at full price. 

All in all, bugs aside, this game is not one to miss.

review:
Welp, this game is kind of clunky, but if you like AC games, it is worth a try. 
The gameplay is OK. Its not a masterpiece, but its managable.
In my opinion, the coop is kinda.... clunky as well. Had a moment where i couldnt finish a mission because the game didnt understand that we've done everything.
But hey, i still reccomend it. Its fun to run around and stuff.
This review is very chaotic, i know.
The combat is a classic, still, it does require a lil bit of precision. (NOTE THERE IS NO WHISTLE OPTION AND NO WAY OF MAKIN A GUARD A MEAT BAG FOR THEM BULLLETS) and thats one of the worst changes in the game.


Still, i liked it and i do recommend it. (maybe pirate it first?)

Anyhow, have a great day!

review: Pretty hot and intense game full of combusting excitement, i particularly liked the realistic lightning of coal and the campfires when you stroll along in this heartwarming town called Paris. If you are a newcomer to the Assassins Creed Series this will be your baptism of fire or in other words a test of faith, expect a lot of hot-bloodedness and smoky action. Dont be stiff like a piece of wood and delve into the action! PS: really nice gesture of ubisoft!

review:
Okay, this game.. this game has issues to state it mildly.. But, hear me out here, I liked it despite that.

The main character is an unlikable P.O.S. who never gains a personality other than a grumpy(read annoying).

The combat is clunky. Like original AC games where you stand around and parry the 14 guys who stand around and occasionally jab at you, except this time you can use a pickaxe as a weapon.. and its badass

The game is buggy and crashes constantly. It sucks less than it did when it came out I think, kinda.

You can pick and choose outfits and colors and really make your assassin hideous, my character had a floppy hood tail and was BRIGHT red.. he was mega disgusting and I loved him. OH, and you look like that in all cutscenes.. its hilarious.

The multiplayer/co-op is trash. that's all

The setting was fun, the running around in Paris was extremely enjoyable compared to the previous games which all had fairly small low to the ground housing and the occasional tower or whatever, Paris feels big and dangerous.

It's a solid 7.5/10, the pickaxe really made this one of my favorite AC games.. seriously laughed way too many times walking through cutscenes as a "serious assassin" dressed as a bright red clown.

review: I didn't get the game when it was free but I strongly believe that this game is great! The graphics are amazing looking, gameplay is good but needs some improvements. The story is good and interesting. The parkour mechanic is awesome and I wish Ubisoft continues to this type of movement. Origins and Odyssey parkour mechanics are good but not in the same level as Unity. However, performance, on my end, is pretty bad and I wish they made a performance fix. To be fair, my GPU is pretty old so I can't complain too much. Overall, great game and with the disaster that happened in Notre Dame, this is a great way to experience one of history's greatest landmarks.

review: This game is great with its atmosphere, parkour, and stellar graphics. The problem comes with the awful and unreliable stealth; noticed how I said unreliable. The game as a total can be unreliable, especially in multiplayer, due to lag, bugs, glitches etc. Another point is how I found gadgets and tools becoming expensive, and there not being many to hold. I also hate the eagle "pulse", the fact no one has French accent (Pierre Bellec is cockney), and other minor points. My main criticism is that, stuff like the parkour, graphics, gear customisation, and parkour, are all held back by poorly implemented features. The multiplayer looked to be amazing but, was horrible in my case with connection. If this game took maybe just another year in development, maybe, just maybe- it could be amazing. 7/10, f**k Elise.

review:
Good guy Ubisoft offering the game free for a while and donating money for Notre Dame. If it wasn't for the very poor launch this game would easily be in my top five for AC games.

However, after many patches it is easily playable and there are a few bugs but it's nothing too bad. 

And what an interesting time for an AC game? French Revolution is easily one of the best times for an AC game to take place.

review:
This Game had a ruth lunch but it is now one of the best AC games to Date. Paris is an incredible city that feels alive and real. The assassination quests are one of the best in the franchise with multiple ways to execute them. 
Even to this date the graphics look amazing and can compete with some games that came out recently. 
If you like the franchise but got put of by the bugs, buy it now cause it's mostly fixed and a great game.

review: This is a game to play if you feel you can enjoy a game for what it does well, while overlooking its flaws. Almost 5 years on, this is one of the most beautiful games that exist. Paris is the star of the show here, so props to Ubisoft's level design team. I also love the stealth emphasis, and actually embodying the role of an assassin. The open mission objectives are done better here than any other AC game. The game's biggest problem is that it needed more polish. It was clearly rushed and not given enough support after the fact to make up for it. I much prefer this style of gameplay though to the RPG heavy origins and odyssey and hope they return to this form in the future.

review:
A good Assassin's Creed game. I had initially tried it on PS4, but the loading times drove me crazy, especially when you had to simply reload a checkpoint. The experience was much more enjoyable on PC.
The context of Revolutionary France is particularly interesting, as well as the storyline and characters. It's always enjoyable to meet all these great historical figures and interact with them.
The game does have its technical issues. It ran very smoothly on my machine, but the pop-ins grow into a distraction. I didn't notice too much at first, but then when I did, it started bothering me. What has been seen cannot be unseen. All of a sudden, you see how objects appear out of thin air, dresses and hats appear magically on bystanders as you approach them. I once even approached a "librairie" only to see it transform into a "boucherie" before my very eyes. Walking back would turn it into "librairie" again.
Other than that, the game still looks rather pretty, and Parisian architecture and monuments certainly help.
There are tons of collectibles and side quests for people with OCD, though sometimes it can be over the top. Having to replay co-op missions three times to unlock every reward was just plain silly, other missions such as the Companion Missions, felt entirely unnecessary.
It truly is a pleasure to parkour through the streets of Paris, though every now and then you get into a ridiculous situation where your character, instead of just running forward, decides he's going to jump on a chair. Trying to get him off the chair will make him jump and grab onto a lamp post, then onto a low railing that's 3 feet off the ground, and it's just painful and cringy to watch, especially if you're in the middle of a chase.
I don't believe the game has much replay value, and I don't even feel like trying the DLC, but you still get bang for your buck when it's on sale at a very low price, if you didn't grab it when it was free after the Notre-Dame fire.

review:
Well I just bought it 3 weeks ago(yeah with real money), I had a bit of discontent (after hearing the free thing) but now I am happy since Ubisoft donated that money! Well back to the game- Amazing graphics (stunning u will surely fall in love), ok story, cool moves(i.e. kills) and a nice recreation of Paris and yeah the myth is true Assassin's Creed teaches History better than in the class! And yeah A wonderful presentation of Notre Dame! Feels real!

well I was gonna ask refund but let it be, may it be contributed to it's recreation and it's pay for value! I can guarantee it's one of the best Assassin's Creed Title ever! At last people understood it's underrated!

review:
I'll say straight away that this Paris is one of the best cities ever in gaming. It's an absolute masterpiece and an achievement. It's then a pitty and a massive disapointment seeing how this game doesn't know how to use it to it's full potential. Gameplay and game design completely destroy a game that could have been something special.

Also the story falls short of what could have been, Arno and Elise are likable protagonists, but the story itself is uninteresting, boring and predictable, which is a shame cause the French Revolution is one of the most fascinating and gripping periods in history ever and should have been used in a better way.

I'll still recomend it, but just because of Paris, it's atmosphere and the fantastic visuals for a 5 year old game.

Oh, and play it French for max immersion :D
review_bomb_reason: Nach dem Brand in der Notre-Dame, die in Assassin's Creed Unity virtuell nachgebildet ist, entschied Entwickler "Ubisoft" das Spiel daraufhin für eine Woche kostenlos auf ihrer Uplay-Plattform zur Verfügung zu stellen und 500.000€ für den Wiederaufbau der Notre-Dame zu spenden. review: Not only did they make an amazing gesture with the Notre Dame disaster by donating money to the reconstruction and the free copies they sold, but the game itself is the core of what Assassins Creed represents, in the good, by making the best parkour so far in the series, the great coop missions to have fun with your friends,the stealth system, which is improved by a lot thanks to a lot of new tools (but without whistling, why ubi) and the beauty of the city of Paris but also in the bad parts, like the typical following up random people, repetitive side missions or the new combat system which is different from older games, but still not as challenging (imo) or fun as other games in the market. On release this game was a disaster, with so many bugs that made this game hated and feared with the bad reviews, but after the patches Unity has almost to no bugs (my PC doesnt  its a must buy if you are a fan pf the AC saga, and very worth buying even if youre not into the saga very much. Ubisoft may be a company that its hard to think that is just good or just bad they made a lot of mistakes, bugs, downgrades and bad games, but also if they work hard like in this game (post patches of course) they make amazing products worth buying. The gesture of Notre Dame and the very good game  itself deserves a positive review.

review:
Graphics took a huge step forward in this game. 
Story has his moment of brilliance but sometime it's weirdly put together.
Gameplay got changed alot from the previous games, sometime very fluid, sometime a few things are clunky.

Multiplayer now has Coop missions. They are really fun, even with randoms, providing that they don't lag.

review:
I can't believe I haven't wrote a review for this yet, so here we go:

I like the settings, the game mechanic is a step up in the right direction from where the previous installment was. The story is a bit shaky, but overall are immersive enough to get swept by in. I love the the theme of the France Revolution. The enviorentment are beautiful and plenty of weapon to customize your character to your liking.

edit: shout out to Ubisoft for the amazing donation to the restoration fund.

review:
+Gorgeous buildings and interiors
+Decent voice acting
+Difficulty increase in combat (you could die even with maxed gear)
+Lots of character customization options
+Multiple weapon types
+Populated cities
+Map is neither too spacious or too claustrophobic
+Smooth combat and fluid animations
+Co-op is fairly interesting and fun
+Clothes physics

+/-British accents
+/-Political themes and elements
+/-No naval combat or vehicles of any kind

-Mediocre storyline
-Forgettable characters
-Enemies cannot parkour unlike in previous titles
-Dependence on multiplayer missions as endgame content
-Lockpocking system feels too game-y
-No assassination target monologue cutscenes
-Less Co-op mission variety than expected for an AC title with dedicated multiplayer PvE content
-Upgraded properties give much more money than the most difficult Heist missions

review:
Great and immersive game, even five years on! Wandering Paris is such a pleasant thrill and pushing your way through the crowds is something I've really missed in a few of the more recent games. It's far from perfect, but it's just too much fun that you can generally ignore a few of its shortcomings (namely the Helix system, the lack of an interactive Modern framing, etc, but, whatever!) and fully enjoy the game for what it is.

Oh, and you can climb Notre Dame - though I am mildly annoyed that they put the 19th Century tower in there, as iconic as it is to the structure these days, it wasn't there in 1798!

review: Overall, I enjoyed this game. I thought the story was good, the gameplay and movement had some significant upgrades over previous games, and the world was both interesting and beautiful. There probably aren't as many bugs as there used to be, but there are still a couple that I ran in to (but they weren't game breakers, just nuisances). The side missions can be repetitive but everything does have a little story to it which is nice. The puzzles are fun to figure out, and some are pretty difficult. There are entirely too many collectibles. In the end, I got 100% sync and it felt like a worthwhile achievement.

review:
+New open ended assasinations are exactly what the Assassin Creed needed
+Fantastic recreation of Paris during the French Revolution
+Large variety of things to do in Paris
+Story tries to added some needed grays areas in the Assassins vs Templar story.
-Alot of pop up and poor AI ruins the emergence. 
-Too much of the same quantity throughout the whole city. Alot should’ve been cut and used to improve performance
-Alot of previous abilities are now hidden behind an unnecessary skill tree.

Overview: Assassin’s Creed Unity updates the Assassin’s Creed formula with a new open ended assassination missions in a rather large map of Paris. Unfortunately it is all let down by poor optimization and a mentality of quantity over quality.

7/10

review: The game still has it's glitches and what not, but if you can look past that there is a lot of beautiful work and dedication that has been put into this game. The game make a solid effort to capture the French Revolution, and as someone who is a huge fan of history in general, it has so much to offer. Gameplay mechanics have been improved considerably from previous games, parkour in particular. When the game goes on sale (or is free like it is right now in support of the Notre Dame incident) grab a copy and give it a shot, it's worth your while.

review:
A lot of people says it's bad and a lot more says is good, which side do I choose? Well I'm on the good review side, for me generally the concept of being a Assassin was all I needed to love this game, it didn't matter to me if I was only doing missions that were point to point, it didn't matter how little amount of things I could do beside missions, or how parts of the story didn't exactly match up with real history and I don't think that is very important anyway since this game isn't to educate you but to entertain you. So if all you kinda cared about was being an Assassin like me then is more than enough. 

However, just because I could be a Assassin and already loving the game at that point really isn't enough to earn a thumbs up since AC allows you to upgrade your skills and Unity specialty is multiplayer so combined those two together for me is more than enough for a thumbs up. Sorry if this review wasn't helpful to you or allowed you to understand the game more but this is my honest opinion.

The toughest enemy in the entire game is the goddamned controls. 
Even after countless patches it's still a little wonky - a little better on controllers, but bless the keyboard + mouse players.

Setting's pretty nice.

Story is frankly a little weak/unconvincing, at least for the starting chapters. 
Didn't play multiplayer mode, so can't comment on that.

Frankly the fantastic setting and atmosphere is carrying the game.

review:
The Best AC game after the classics AC1 and 2 with great atmosphere in my opinion. There're plently of glitches, but even those are mostly funny. I liked literally everything, exept of not seeing my enemies in combat sometimes and desynching in coops for no reason. 

+ Graphics
+ Coops
+ A lot of different missions
+ Multiple weapon types 
+ Abbility to choose your own style
+ Controls


- Glitches, more of GL!""§TCH%&ES 
(forgivable, because it's a huge Project and was obviously not that simple in deviloping. It's out and more or less stable, thnx)

- The story of main charakter was not so clear 
(but it's not that important. The character looks nice and the game has a logical line)

- The most difficult mission is to get into any opened window in this game.


P.s. Ubisoft, please come back to the old style of AC games, that you deviloped till 2016. Here's the purest estethic pleasure (:

review:
Assassin’s Creed Unity is a game of impossible peaks and disappointing valleys. Its highs of movement, customization options, and just the city of Paris itself pierce the sky like the spire of Notre Dame. On a purely technical level, Unity is a marvel to walk through and admire. But at the same time, a lot of my journey through the French Revolution felt as cold and heartless as the darkest depths of the catacombs. I was never given a real reason to care about new Assassin Arno, or the events that transpired. Instead, I had to find my own fun throughout my 30 hours in Unity, which was generally easy to do in its large sandbox assassination scenarios. However, it’s a bit disappointing to see how few of the long-standing problems with the series have been solved by the upgrade to the new generation of gaming hardware.
Each of the various districts unfolds with its own sense of character and environmental storytelling, from the ornate palaces of the privileged, to back-alleys running with the blood of the revolutionaries. But what makes it really unique and distinct from past games is its citizens, who form some of the largest, most impressive crowds I've ever encountered. 
The disgruntled masses make it even more of a necessity to scurry along rooftops instead of the streets, and thankfully, this mode of transportation does not disappoint. Most of the time, traversal in Unity feels better than ever thanks to fantastic animations, buildings with plenty of climbable paths, and a new downward parkour system that adds certain finesse to the act of shimming down a wall, resolving one of my big gripes with previous AC games.

review:
Despite the controversy surrounding the glitchy mess this game released with - The game is an amazing adventure with stunning graphics and fantastic landscapes. The story fell short for a lot of people, but I personally thought it was better than most. 
Since most of the bugs and glitches have been patched out, I definitely can recommend this game - which is made even more fun by playing through it's unique Co-Op experience.

review:
I was actually surprised at how much I like this game. I didn't like any of the games set in the American colonies because they lacked the very thing I loved about the earlier Creed titles. That is the gorgeous iconic buildings situated in the legendary cities of the Old World. I didn't buy this title when it came out because of the technical problems but I haven't encountered any glitches at all in the current version. 
I don't know how they managed to fill the streets with so many NPC's, many more than the newer games. It really brings the city to life. It's really sad that the game's release was blighted by technical problems because it really is an exceptional achievement. I would have paid full price for the game in it's current state so anyone getting this free really scored. I may even go back and try to finish Black Flag.

review: To me this was the best and probably still is the best AC to come out yet. Unfortunately there were some limitation issues and perhaps some coding issues they ran into that still leaves npc's randomly changing outfits consistently, so it hasn't been received well. However, if you can get past the unfortunate issues it still has in it, there is a top notch AC game here with superior climbing and all around movement mechanics; amazing world design; unique for it's time leveling system (at least in this series); and one of the best stories thus far. I HIGHLY recommend this game and hope they aren't sticking with the annoyingly "souls like" wannabe mechanics they are using in ACO and ACO lol.

review: This is basically a walking simulator.  Stay away.
review_bomb_reason: Die Entwickler "Campo Santo" reichten eine DMCA-Beschwerde gegen ein Video ein, das der bekannte YouTuber "PewDiePie" zu Firewatch gemacht hatte (d.h. er wurde gezwungen, das Video zu entfernen), nachdem PewDiePie während eines seiner Livestreams eine rassistische Bemerkung geäußert hatte. Viele Spieler gaben daraufhin negative Bewertungen zu Firewatch ab und bezeichneten die Entwickler als "Social Justice Warrior" (SJW), oder behaupteten sie würden Zensur unterstützen.

review: Even though the game is rather pretty for a walking simulator and has well written voice acting, the developers actions of late really put a lot into perspective on how they abuse DMCA. Even though you can disagree with what I said, it's not right to target specific people for what they said if they didn't say it while playing your game, or take back consent that you already gave. This is no better than forcing a video review to be taken down because you didn't want a bad review.

review:
I can't recommend buying this game as the developers are attacking the livelihood of youtubers (Felix Kjellberg AKA Pewdiepie)  who they have deemed to be racist for saying a racial slur on stream (not even streaming firewatch at the time) by filing DMC claims against them and encouraging others to as well.  As if racial slurs aren't common place in competitive gaming and various forms of music.

They have also been banning and censoring people on their various forums for discussing this issue as well.

I refuse to support this behaviour from game developers and I strongly encourage you to as well.
